div.p: Greetings. I have nothing at present worthy of writing, except that the people of Rouen are competing in audacity and stubbornness with the Parisians.
Therefore, one of the marshals has been sent to restrain their fury and ensure the safety of our people.
It would not be difficult to quell all the tumults; indeed, they would subside on their own, if the queen did not secretly support them with her arts.
She pretends otherwise; yet it is certain that through emissaries she acts in such a way that what has been openly decreed in the king's council is rendered null by the wickedness of worthless men.
Indeed, the impunity of crimes sufficiently shows that she approves of whatever aims to oppress us.
What the admiral is thinking, I do not know.
Yesterday I received letters from him, in which he only indicates to me and Beza that he will soon send a man on purpose, through whom he will inform us of his plan.

However, from the letters of Subisius, who was with him, I infer that he is still avoiding the court, partly because he does not want to risk rashly, partly to avoid being compelled to undertake an expedition against the English.

Count of Sausens, the prefect of Lyon, with whom I had no previous acquaintance, congratulates me on the peaceful state of the city; however, they stubbornly refuse to admit our provincials; they will eventually have to be subdued by arms, and despair drives them headlong.
Farewell, most illustrious man, my sincerely revered brother. Many greetings to all colleagues, to your wife and the whole family.
May the Lord keep you all safe!
Your Ionville respectfully and sincerely greets you.
